Award.AwardTitle: Using Topology Optimization to Reduce Support Structures in Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing represents a class of processes for fabricating parts of virtually any shape through material addition. The technique, often called 3D printing, offers several advantages over traditional manufacturing, and has the potential to revolutionize the way things are made. However, to fully exploit additive manufacturing, new design methods are needed. This award supports fundamental research towards developing a design framework for additive manufacturing. The design framework will not only consider traditional performance metrics but also additive manufacturing constraints. Specifically, the award will focus on the reduction of the sacrificial support structures needed to additively manufacture parts with geometric overhangs. By departing from conventional practice for support-structure design, the project's integrated approach will lead to low-cost products, benefitting the U.S. economy and society. Developing the framework involves several disciplines including design, manufacturing, and computer science. The research will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups and positively impact engineering education.

This research will leverage topology optimization theory to integrate performance metrics and additive manufacturing constraints. For example, it will help minimize the compliance of the part, while respecting support structure constraints. The framework will be sufficiently general to accommodate a variety of performance metrics such as compliance, stress, and buckling, and a variety of additive manufacturing constraints such as support structures, surface roughness, and fabrication time. Robust level-set methods of topology optimization will be combined with augmented Lagrangian formulations to create a design framework that will then be integrated into these existing computer aided design systems and made available to the public. Experimental calibration and validation will be carried out to support the theory. The focus will largely be on polymer fused deposition modeling since this process is both inexpensive and easily accessible. However, experiments will also be carried out on metal additive manufacturing to establish the broader implications of the findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background

Additive manufacturing (AM) represents a broad class of processes for fabricating parts of virtually any shape through material addition. The technique, often referred to as 3D printing, offers several advantages over traditional manufacturing, and has the potential to revolutionize the way engineering artifacts are made. However, one of the challenges in AM, specifically in the popular powder-bed AM, is the need for support structures. Support structures assist in the AM build process but must be later removed. This adds to the cost of fabrication, material, and post-processing.

Intellectual Merit

Through this award, the team developed novel methods to redesign parts for AM, such that the amount of support needed is reduced, but without sacrificing on the performance of the part. The methods developed through this award relied on computational techniques, by extending the mathematical concept of topological sensitivity. Topological sensitivity is a precise way of predicting the impact of a design change on the performance of a part. The performance measure could be, for example, the ability of the part to withstand a given load without failure (other measures can be defined by the engineer). While the concept of topological sensitivity is well known, the team at the University of Wisconsin, Madison extended this concept by also predicting the impact of a design change on the support structure needed to build the part. In other words, two types of topological sensitivities were developed: one for predicting the impact of design change on performance, and the other for predicting the impact of design change on the support structure needed. The team then combined the two to optimally design parts to meet performance requirements, while minimizing support needed. Several case-studies were developed to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Parts were designed using traditional methods and compared against the proposed method. The team was able to reduce support structures by up to 35%, without sacrificing on performance.

Broader Impacts

The methods developed through this award has numerous broader impacts. The first and immediate impact is on the cost savings, due to the reduced support structure needed. Our estimate is that, for typical parts built by AM, the material cost saving, on the average, is about 12%, without loss in performance. In addition, time and labor savings can also be expected (but were hard to quantify). The design engineer can also use the proposed method to make trade-offs between cost and performance. The methodology could potentially be extended to other manufacturing processes such as casting and extrusion, by further extending the concept of topological sensitivity to such manufacturing processes. Four graduate students were trained through this award. The students were not only trained to develop computationally efficient algorithms, but also to use the metal AM machines. Understanding the relationship between computational algorithms and their
real-world manifestation has been the main focus of professional development. Several journal papers and a book chapter were published; the students also got an opportunity to present their findings at technical conferences. Finally, through this grant, manufacturing cost and engineering analysis was unified through a quantifiable measure, bringing the two disciplines closer.

 


Last Modified: 12/14/2020
Modified by: Krishnan Suresh
